title: In the book 'Flowers for Algernon', why does Dr Strauss tell Charlie that he'll have more problems as he becomes more intelligent? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because the secret is that most smart people are useless and they know it. The joy of being dumb is that you don't know that you're a useless cog in the machine. The smarter you are, the more you know. The more you know, the more people hate you, the more you notice how people talk down to you, the more you you know how much more there is to learn, the more you know that you can never make a difference. “Flowers for Algernon" is a great book though.

Because he'll have more of an ability to register problems away from himself. In the beginning Charlie's life is so simple work and go to school and his problems are pretty simple around that. As he gets more intelligent he tries to understand things apart from him more and has relationships and has to try to upkeep them. He understands not just the problems he has today but the problems humanity will have tomorrow.
